docs.lead_paragraph: The musicians and management of the New York Philharmonic have agreed to a new labor contract on the eve of an 18-day tour in Asia. The contract raises salaries at six-month intervals so that by the end of the three-year agreement, in 2007, the Philharmonic's minimum wage, now $103,000, will rise to $113,360. However, the orchestra will no longer be the highest paid in the country, lagging slightly behind the Boston Symphony.
docs.abstract: New York Philharmonic management and musicians agree to new three-year labor contract that would raise salaries at six-month intervals to $113,360 from $103,000; largest raises come toward end of contract; parties delay discussing pensions until next season; both sides express happiness with deal (M)
docs.snippet: The new Philharmonic contract raises musicians' salaries to $113,360, but the orchestra will no longer be the highest paid in the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: DRAPED in a blue apron, a supermarket clerk squatted on a parking lot curb, taking a break from work at a Safeway supermarket in an affluent neighborhood here. ''I make about 10 bucks an hour,'' he said. ''I don't know how they expect us to pay for health care out of that.''

headline.main: The Health Care Clash Moves to the Next Aisle

docs.abstract: Health care continues at center of union disputes as supermarket chain struggle to contain runaway costs that hinder competition with nonunion rivals like Wal-Mart; photo; employers in general, main providers of health care coverage in US, are shifting more benefit costs to workers; example is two-tier wage and benefit system accepted by Safeway workers in Califonria and by workers at Giant and Safeway stores in Washington, DC (M)
docs.snippet: Supermarkets face a new showdown as labor unions determined to keep health benefits spar with management trying to compete with Wal-Mart.

docs.lead_paragraph: A DRUG that helps people lose weight and stop smoking ought to be a big seller, but when Sanofi-Aventis, the French pharmaceutical company, announced success in trials of just such a drug, the company's stock barely budged. A few days later, in early September, American regulators recommended that AstraZeneca, the British drug maker, not be given permission to market an anticlotting drug, citing safety concerns. There was no muted reaction this time: the stock sank as much as 6 percent the next day.

headline.main: One Eye on Drug Stocks, the Other on Election Day

docs.abstract: Investing article on outlook for large-cap pharmaceutical stocks; sector is underperforming as investors continue to react to negative events, such as recalls, and ignore positive developments; photo; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: Investors' fear that drug prices will be hurt under a Kerry presidency has sent the stocks of many pharmaceutical companies lower.

docs.lead_paragraph: While presidential candidates and economists fiercely debate the strength of the job market's recovery, that expansion is tilting heavily toward part-time jobs rather than full-time employment. More than one million of the 1.2 million jobs added this year are part time, the Labor Department says, and part-time jobs now represent 18 percent of the overall job market, the highest level since 1997.

headline.main: When 'Job' Means Part Time, Life Becomes Very Different

docs.abstract: Job market expansion is tilting heavily toward part-time jobs rather than full-time employment, accounting for more than one million of the 1.2 million jobs added this year; Labor Dept says part-time jobs now represent 18 percent of overall job market, highest level since 1997; implications of trend discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Part-time jobs now represent 18 percent of the overall job market, the highest level since 1997.

docs.lead_paragraph: Speculators Still Bullish on Bush The instant polls gave Senator John Kerry the edge in Friday night's debate. The punditocracy generally called it a draw. But the online speculators betting real money on the election -- the ones who probably have the best track record at instant analysis -- seemed more impressed by President Bush at the end of the debate.
docs.abstract: John Tierney Political Points column says online speculators give Pres Bush 55 percent chance in election based on debate performance; notes Kerry's inability to connect with audience; finds Bush most appealing in his unscripted moments with plain-spoken approach; drawings; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Online speculators, who were betting real money on the election, seemed more impressed by President Bush at the end of Friday's debate.

docs.lead_paragraph: MICHAEL A. KNOX thought he had run out of ways to pay off his credit card bills when he got the salesman's call two years ago. To wipe out his nearly $20,000 debt, he was told, all he had to do was take out a new, bigger mortgage on his house. Mr. Knox, then 60 and on disability, signed up. The mortgage broker sent him eight checks already made out to his creditors, and Mr. Knox dashed to the post office the day they arrived to mail them.

headline.main: Erase Debt Now. (Lose Your House Later.)

docs.abstract: Millions of Americans have taken advantage of low interest rates and rising home values to refinance mortgages, using proceeds to pay off credit cards and other debts, but many of them have also ended up losing or almost losing homes to creditors; several case histories recounted; photos; debt consolidation industry, which has estimated four million outstanding loans, has enabled many people with modest incomes to own homes but last year more than 16 percent of subprime mortages were delinquent or in foreclosure (M)
docs.snippet: Michael Knox, along with tens of thousands of others, lost his home by using his house to pay off his credit card bills.

docs.lead_paragraph: HAVING taught English in Smithtown for a few years, Victor Jaccarino was considering a move to the Herricks school district. ''I called somebody at Herricks and told them that my partner had AIDS and I was gay,'' he recalled. His contact, a school official who has since left the district, told Mr. Jaccarino to come anyway. But when he arrived in 1993, the official told him to stay in the closet.

headline.main: Out of the Closet, Into the Classroom

docs.abstract: Article on Long Island Gay-Straight Educators Assn, group formed over summer to help educators who are gay or actively helping gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender students in their schools (M)
docs.snippet: HAVING taught English in Smithtown for a few years, Victor Jaccarino was considering a move to the Herricks school district.    ''I called somebody at Herricks and told them that my partner had AIDS and I was gay,'' he recalled. His contact, a school...

docs.lead_paragraph: For the voters assembled in the Executive Conference Room of the baronial old Pfister Hotel in downtown Milwaukee on Friday night, it was not a question of who won and who lost the second presidential debate of the 2004 campaign. Most of them did not want to discuss it in such terms. Like the people who questioned President Bush and Senator John Kerry in St. Louis, all of the 11 here had described themselves as either undecided or still persuadable. What they were looking for was more detailed answers, covering more policy areas, they said. After watching the 90-minute confrontation, many of them said they were disappointed by what they had heard and still searching for the information they needed.

headline.main: Debate Leaves Some Milwaukee Voters Still in Doubt

docs.abstract: New York Times assembled group of eleven undecided voters in Milwaukee, Wis, to view October 8 debate and discuss it afterwards; no clear-cut patterns emerge from post-debate discussions; there is no unanimous position among younger voters, women or African-Americans; most say they did not get information they need to make up their minds; some say attention on Iraq obscures domestic issues, others feel Iraq is most important issue; all want more specific information on candidates' positions on various issues; photo (M)
docs.snippet: After watching the 90-minute confrontation on Friday, many of the 11 voters assembled in a downtown Milwaukee hotel said they were still searching for the information they needed.

byline.original: By R. W. APPLE Jr.; John Files contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine that you have heart failure. What can medicine do for you? It depends: are you white or black? If you're white, your doctor may prescribe one of the drugs that seem to ease the symptoms, maybe a beta-blocker or an ACE inhibitor. And if you're black, your doctor may still prescribe those drugs, but they might not really help. That's about to change. In the not-too-distant future, if you're black and have heart failure, drug-company researchers predict you'll be able to go to the doctor and walk out with a prescription tailor-made for you. Well, not tailor-made, exactly, but something that seems to work in people a lot like you. Well, not a lot like you, exactly, except that they're black, too. In this not-too-distant future, if you're black, your doctor will be able to prescribe BiDil, the first drug in America that's being niche-marketed to people of a particular race -- our first ethnic medicine.

headline.main: The Genome in Black and White (and Gray)

docs.abstract: Robin Marantz Henig article on research in which some scientists are studying genetic basis of race in order to develop better treatments; emerging field of race-based pharmacogenomics signals shift in perception, new approach that has as its core idea assumption that there are biological differences among races; frustrating gap in health status of different racial groups refuses to close or even to be adequately explained, and scientists remain split on very concept of race; pitfalls of research include possible misinterpretation of data that could lead to sweeping pronouncements and racial disharmony; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: Research scientists are increasingly studying the genetic basis of race. It could lead to better medicine, or to new kinds of stereotypes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Electric Company's third-quarter earnings rose 11 percent and revenue jumped 15 percent as a rebounding economy and acquisitions drove a sharp increase in orders, the company said Friday. G.E. -- the industrial, financial services and media conglomerate -- said it earned $4.05 billion, or 38 cents a share, in the period, up from $3.65 billion, or 36 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $38.3 billion, up from $33.4 billion a year ago.

headline.main: G.E.'s Earnings Rise 11%, Driven by Surge in Orders

docs.abstract: General Electric Co's third-quarter earnings rose 11 percent and revenue jumped 15 percent; earned $4.05 billion in period, up from $3.65 billion year earlier; revenue was $38.3 billion, up from $33.4 billion year ago (M)
docs.snippet: The results matched the consensus estimate of 38 cents per share with health care and transportation among the businesses with a jump in orders.
